author: wired blogs
text: date: mon, 15 nov 1999 13:44:06 -0800 from: lyle bateman (batemanl@cadvision.com)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: re: riaa suing upstart startupthis lawsuit, if won, would be a frightening legal precedent ("riaa suing upstart startup," 15.nov.99). this issue here, it seems to me is not whether the napster software can be used for illegal purposes, or even if it is being used for illegal purposes. practically every product on the market can be used illegally. the issue here is whether or not the software has a legitimate, legal use. if so, then napster has every right to produce and market it.as has been pointed out in many previous articles, there are many legal mp3s on the net. where riaa should focus their attention is on the individuals using the software with pirated content, not on a company that has produced software with a legitimate, legal purpose.
